title: Inateck FE3001 Hard Disk Drive Enclosure Mounting Bracket

description.text:
The openSCAD script provides a configurable mounting bracket for use with the Inateck FE3001 Aluminum USB 3.0 Hard Disk Drive Enclosure. Product link: https://www.inateck.com/inateck-fe3001-3-5-usb-3-0-superspeed-hdd-external-enclosure.html

The bracket can be prepared so that the drive enclosure is mounted in a lay-flat configuration, or in an upright, on-edge configuration. A top-level geometry section of the script allows the user to specify the desired openSCAD result. Two components are provided. One serves as a wrap-around for the drive enclosure, and the second component serves as a base.

The wrap component can be configured with a closed bottom and used alone for a low-profile mount. Configuring the wrap component with an "open" bottom allows it to be "sprung" over an assembled enclosure with the OEM rubber feet installed. Here, use of the base component can be used to help stabilize the open-bottom wrap component when mounting the enclosure. The base component also increases the gap available for convection airflow cooling between the enclosure and the mounting surface.

STL files have provided for both the lay-flat and upright brackets with open-bottom wrap components. Two brackets would typically be used to mount the enclosure.

author: Printbus

description.text:
A standard folding table, suitable for garage sales, canvassing, or accommodating more figures for the big holiday meal.

To make the table, print one tabletop and two copies of the legs. The legs should snap into the tabletop without much trouble. If they're tight, try cleaning up the holes with a needle file. You don't want them too loose though, so I recommend just snapping them in and working them back and forth a bit.

I think it looks especially good if you print the tabletop in white and the legs in gray or silver, so I've included plates with two tabletops and four legs to make it easier to print multiples, if you like.

Be sure to check out the rest of our Thanksgiving files:

  • folding chair
  • plates
  • roast turkey
  • pies

Enjoy!

If you like this sort of thing and want to see more, be sure to follow us on Twitter and/or join the discussion on our Facebook page

It's compatible with the makerbot.com style mechanical end stops.

You get them from here as an example:

https://www.banggood.com/6Pcs-Mechanical-End-Stop-Endstop-Limit-Switch-With-Cable-For-CNC-3D-Printer-RAMPS-1_4-p-1073096.html?rmmds=search&cur_warehouse=CN

Wire the Pin 1 and Pin 3 (Endstop) to the Pin 9 and 10 (Pii). You don't have to care about polarity.

author: stonecoldfx

title: Binary Numbers, Base Two System, Place Values

description.text:
A scaffold for children to learn about binary numbers or numbers in the base two number system (0 to 11111, corresponding to 0 to 31 in the base ten system). The stand has five positions and is about 120mm long. It takes five number pieces to play the binary game (ranging 0 from 31).

The number piece has "1" on the front and "0" on the back. I have designed the numbers for easy sliding and 3D printing. Have fun!
CCSS

There is little doubt that children today need to have a working knowledge of the base two system.  It is also helpful for them to develop insight into the common base-ten system.  Indeed, any number can be equivalently representations on any base B (B>1).

There are many ways to use the binary game board. Here is one way to interact with a child.
To begin with, ask a child to think of a number between 0 and 31 without revealing it to you. Then, you ask, "Is your number bigger or equal to 16?" If the answer is yes, then place a "1" in the 16 slot and subtract 16 from the original number to get the remaining number. Otherwise, place "0" in the 16 slot and move on. Ask similar questions about the left-over using 8, 4, 2, and 1, placing either "1" or "0" in the corresponding slot. The result is the base-two representation of the child's original number. It is essentially binary sorting using the place values.

description.text:
Check out the video here for the design and testing of the Flying Auger.

For the Teal Drone Cover Remix contest I made a flying auger cover that drops seeds as the drone flies. Seeds do best when covered with some soil but they can still thrive when tossed on top of soil. With this design you can add seeds into the hopper, replace the cover, and fly away dropping seeds as you go. Featuring a 629:1 propeller:auger gear ratio which means the auger spins nice and slowly to allow slow dispersal of seeds, and high torque so the auger won't get stuck. Easily spread wildflower seeds over an entire hilltop or spread grass seed over a large lawn. Empty weight is 163 g.

Printer:

Qidi X-One

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15 mm

Infill:

13%

Notes:

Overall most things can be printed up to .3 mm thick, but files with threads should be printed at .15 mm or less. The rod is the hardest to print and works best with multiple touching outlines to anchor the parts to the table a little more. Print them slow and hot to help keep drag to a minimum.

This is an attempt to repair the back wheels of an Evenflo stroller. The wheel hub breaks after some usage and I have seen strollers on street with broken wheels.

I bored out the hub which included the broken plastic on a drill press. I then measured the inside, and designed and printed a new hub. The design was done using Inventor, and printed with a MakerGear Prusa RepRap printer. The trick was to print with 100% infill for added strength. remixed_from.title: Creality CR-10 Caliper Mount for Bed Level/Tramming!

title: Semi-Auto bed-leveler -- Creality stock printhead mount.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CallJoe shared a neat idea (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2524480) about using low-cost digital tire-tread gauges as a "semi-automatic" bed leveler.

Unlike the paper-under-the-nozzle method where you guess whether that's enough friction on the page or not, or the auto methods where you hope the probe senses the bed before crashing (where the sensitivity can change wildly with the bed's temp), in this method, you get the printhead to the test point, then lower the probe and read the number. (more details on a procedure below in the "how-to")

This version also is designed to permanently mount on the head, so there's minimal slop in the measurements, and the structure can print without any supports. There is a gap engraved into the top so the battery case can be slid open, so hopefully this is something you mount and never need to pull off again.

This version of the probe is designed to mount on the holes on the right side of the stock Creality print head, right where the stock autoleveler would mount. This means it doesn't interfere with any other stock functions, since the part it displaces (the auto-leveler) is the part it replaces. If you've opted for a part-fan mount on the right, there are printable mounts for the left side as well, and the vents on the left side are non-functional so it wouldn't interfere..

The mount itself is designed with recessed screw holes so the M2x8mm sockethead screws Creality is fond of for sensors (and may be in your spare parts bag) are the perfect size . . . and match the threaded holes on the right side.

While I've tuned this print to line up with the Ender 4 gantry, I wouldn't be surprised if this also works well with all the Creality printers using this shroud.

Printer:

Creality Ender 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

My prototypes were printed at 0.3/7% and came out fine, but warped a bit more than I care. Anything below 0.2mm/layer is overkill for this part. Adding a few more percent filled in the infill grid a lot, so I recommend at least 10%, but 20% looks about right (my final one was at 20%.

I printed mine in ABS, since it stays with the print head, right next to the hot bits. I don't recommend normal/low temp PLA -- it'll probably be fine, but the lower hook sits right next to the insulated heater block the whole print . . . your call, but if you do, watch it on the first print or two for softening.

post processing is simple

-- retract the probe into the tool, then slip the tool into the socket display first (the outside edge is the bottom print surface). the probe should be tight in the socket and flush with the back.

-- check the screw holes. You may need to ream out the holes first (an exacto knife will do), depending on how well your slicer/printer did.

-- insert a screw then align the bottom tabs with the back bottom ledge on the right hand side of the print head. the top two tabs should slide over the top of the cowling and the screw holes should be close enough to start a few threads with only a little bit of lateral adjustment.

-- tighten both screws down fully. you'll need a 1.5mm hex bit for this. Getting them started can be a touch tricky. Once they're tight, check for a firm hold and double check that nothing is binding.

you're now ready to semi-auto level.

I imported CallJoe's STL file into Sketchup -- pretty simple model, so it's easy to manipulate.

Once in Sketchup, I mirrored the part to reverse it, cut out the window in the base for the display to pass through, cut a notch so it wouldn't interfere with the belt, created the alignment tabs roughly where I measured them on the head, and created screw holes according to measurements . . . and printed a draft.

First draft, the screws were too short (recessed the heads and countersunk so they don't need support) , the gap at the top for the slide was too close (it was rubbing on the right side) and there was WAY too much plastic above the printhead mounts (time to trim and curve. fixed . . . and print a second draft . . .

Second draft was almost right. holes were a little high, a little small, and too close together, and the outer edge needed to be beveled . . . you know, for finish ;) Made the changes and printed a third draft . . .

. . . and that is what I'm using today. Double checked it across Cura, CraftWare and Slic3r for obvious print issues (I don't have S3D) , so it should be makeable :)

How-To (semi-auto leveling in action)

So far, the best way I've found is to level the bed is like how you tune a stringed instrument -- get the first point where you like it, then tune the rest of the points to that. For the first point, set the height either with a page under the first point (if care to go by feel), or raise the bed until the nozzle is pressed into the bed by the springs, measure the point, add 0.1 to 0.3mm (depending on how tight you want your first layer to be), and lower the bed until it hits the adjusted value (tapping the top of the slide gently to remeasure every time you turn the knob) . . . then use the newly measured "level" value to set the remaining points.

Come up to a "next" point, if the probe moves as the print head is set down, then that side is too high. Turn the nob a touch (to the left) and gently tap the top of the slide to get it to re-measure the length -- stop when you get to the "level" value.

If the probe doesn't move when you get to the "next" spot, gently tap the top to see if the probe moves downward or is resting on the bed -- if the number increases, it wasn't resting on the bed, and you need to move that point upward (right). careful as you turn the knob that you don't lift the bed, moving the probe upward -- before you read each measurement, always gently tap the top of the slide to ensure the probe is resting on the bed.

If the probe doesn't move and when you tap it, and it's at the "level" value, then congratulations, that point is level with the first one -- you're ready to move to the next.

It's far less guesswork than sliding paper around and doesn't mar your fresh (Ha!) layer of PVA on your glass bed. when the bed is close, it's pretty quick, and when your bed is right, it'll move through the autolevel routine almost as fast as you can hit "next"

print_settings.Notes:: Simplify3D

description.text:
Summary

A case/enclosure for a LM386 Mini Power Amplifier Module.

There are many different designs for this amplifier module. Mine were purchased from Wish and have the ICStation branding (ICSK025A) and all measurements were taken from one of those boards. If anyone makes this design for a different but similar module, let me know if the dimensions are close or correct. Most of the parts look to be in similar positions on other similar modules, but I'm guessing there are some slight differences.

ICSK025A Modules

From your favorite retailer. These all appear to be the same ICSK025A module.

Ali Express
Ebay
ICStation
NewEgg
Wish

Notes

I wanted to make a case that was as small as possible and still functional. There are two options for the lid, one with a vented lid, one without. The lid is a friction fit. The module takes a certain bit of twisting and a small amount of case bending to get the 3 protrusions on three different faces to line up, but it can be done. The hole in the right wall is used to pass through a jumper cable or wire for an external speaker or output.

Dimensions

My finished case measures approximately 45.2 mm (W) x 44.2 mm (L) x 32.5 mm (H) and was printed with Silver Metallic Ultimaker Filament

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Slicer: Simplify3D
Nozzle: 0.04 mm
Layer Height: 0.02 mm
Top Solid Layers: 4
Bottom Solid Layers: 3
Shells: 2
Infill Type: Full Honeycomb
Speed: 2500 mm/min (41.6667 mm/sec)

Parts for Assembly

4 ea. M3 5 mm Screws
1 ea. 3.18 x 6.35 mm Rubber Grommet

I used 4 ea. M3 5 mm screws to hold it down, but if you put a nut on the potentiometer, that would probably be sufficient once all the jacks are aligned. I also used a 3.18 x 6.35 mm rubber grommet for the right side speaker wire passthrough.

Took minutes to model these coil springs in Inventor, using helix option. Unlike wire springs it is easy to add a torus top and bottom to make more stable to print. On second attempt I added some thin stiffeners in 4 angular positions to stop spring moving during print. These are easy to pick out with a fine file after the print is complete and results in less stalactites on underside of coil. Springs are a bit soft - if you print at 80% scale you get a 0.5" dia x 1" long spring.

After seeing the devastating wildfires in my home state of California, I wanted to try and do something to make a change. Then I saw this design competition an knew I had to make this. This drone top cover, when not the prettiest, packs a lot of functionality. First, it has an MQ-2 Gas sensor for helping firefighters know if an area is safe to breathe in, as the sensor detects Smoke. This sensor also detects flammable gas so it can let a firefighter know if an area is in danger. The second sensor is a high-temperature thermistor, the type used in 3d-printers. This can help detect hot spots and help the drone operator know where a fire is if he or she loses sight of the drone. This top cover also allows for actual firefighting too.You can string a large rubber band between the horn of the servo and the hook on the opposite side of the drone, and then put a fire retardant ball, such as this https://www.amazon.com/Extinguisher-Suppression-Device-Safety-Product/dp/B01JVXFQ6E , under the drone, and held by the rubber band. Now when the servo is turned, the fire retardant ball will drop which will then explode spraying the fire with retardant, extinguishing it. All of these sensors and servos have holes that will allow you to wire them to the drones electronics. Depending on the flight controller used in the teal drone, the sensors could read live to an open-tx compatible controller. The servo could be easily plugged into a receiver. While this drone won't stop a wildfire, it can provide firefighters with a new angle to attack the fire with, and can provide them with tools to ade safety and the ability to extinguish house fires.

The crash bars in my office require a certain size hex key to secure them in the "unlocked" position.

This locks the bar in place, so we don't need the hex key anymore.

V2 works much better. The forces on it don't force a bend. It's been in use for over two months with no warpage.

Wearable Cubone Skull Helmet. Perfect for your Cubone Cosplay.

Printed on the Anycubic I3 MEGA which has a build area of 210 mmx 210mm x 205mm.

Pokemon Fans: Check out my Real Working Fully Functional 3D Printed PokeDex

Instructions
Print out all 8 "CB" pieces - Some may require supports and many will require rotating to reduce support material.

The "Cube.stl" piece should be printed about 8 times and sticks into square shaped holes in each of the other pieces to help align the pieces when gluing.

I glued the pieces together with Loctite Super Glue Ultra Gel Control

After gluing I filled in the cracks at the seams with ELMER'S Probond Woodfiller, let it dry and then sanded down the extra wood filler.

Finally, I painted it with Rust-oleum White Primer: Flate White

And for extended wearing, I'd recommend gluing in some foam to protect your head

comments.author: RevaHolmes

comments.text: The needle does break easily (and I even made it bigger so it would break less)... Though I'm not familiar with how the Anet A8 prints, it sounds like it could be a slicer problem... if you have support around the needle make it be less dense so the needle won't break off when you are removing the support.  If that isn't the problem, then maybe it's not being printed with enough shells/infill... make sure there's at least 2 outline perimeters.  There are some other slicer settings that could affect it too -- the ones that control thin walled prints, also the extrusion multiplier.  I hope something of this helps :)  I know we have one printer here at home that's great and another one that does terrible at little thin details (like the needle)... Good luck!!

title: Simple LED driver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model is a means of driving and dimming your LED’s.
By changing (or switch off) the light intensity of the LED in different ways, you get different colors and effects. This is the main secret of the lamps I have posted this year.
It’s the simplest way I could think of to make this driver/ dimmer :-).
Basically it’s just a case with 3 potentiometers and 3 transistors (or FET can also be used like a BUZ11)
that dims the voltage. This is a follow up part for the adjustable LED base: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2660485.
If you have your LED’s and the right resistor (I have talked about in https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2660485) you can make this driver case. I included a schematic for connecting the parts. Because it’s so simple, I didn’t even make a PCB, but soldered the parts directly together on the potentiometers themselves. The transistor is only needed to handle the current and it’s cheaper than buying a 5W potentiometer.
The 15K resistor is just a limiter so the potentiometer has a better range. If the range does not work for you because the LED is already at max level when the potentiometer shaft is only at 50%, than you can replace this resistor with a 50K potentiometer to “fine tune” it.
Than you need a case to hold the parts together and I kept it very simple. There is a main housing end 2 different type of baseplates. One has extra mounting options. Also the one with external mounting option has a build in cable tie. The basic one without the external mounting options does not have this cable tie option but slots for cable ties. In the photos the white case is the one with build in cable ties
I also made a knob. It fits the potentiometers I used. Please see the photo for the dimensions.
This driver works on a USB charger, but I also use 12V adapters with an LM7805. This 12V solution has a great disadvantage, because you waste a lot of energy in the form of heat (and a LM7805,100nF &33nF capacitor) :-). So my advice is to buy a cheap 2.1A USB charger.

The goal of this driver is to make it cheap. Do you have 3 50 potentiometers? Use them then. Do you not have this transistor but A BUZZ11 or an IRFZ44N? use those. That is wat it will keep it cheap. The more parts you have to buy, the more expensive it will get :-).

Maybe I will make a PWM driven driver in the future, but only if people ask me

title: HCEvo Chimera Mount with 12mm Inductive Sensor

description.text:
2018-01-25: I haven't forgotten about this design, just been very busy with school holidays. I'll be completing and validating the design in the next week or two. The printer I'll be using it with will have a pair of Volcano hotends, so I'll make a version for both the standard heatblock and the Volcano. Maybe one will work for both, I'm not sure.. :-)

2017-12-02: beta 2 design uploaded, which has the mount positioned quite a bit lower. The first test design was never going to work, as the sensor would have been mounted way too high. I've yet to properly dimension things so there may be some more adjustments yet to come.

A bit of a Tinkercad hack job project to modify einarms' Chimera mount for the Hypercube Evolution, so that it can hold as 12mm inductive sensor.

Please note that I haven't yet printed it out, but it slices nicely in Simplify3D and its preview shows no issues with needing further supports or isolated areas. The few things I've yet to ensure are:

  • the probe (and its two mounting nuts) don't foul the Chimera and/or the part cooling fan
  • the probe doesn't foul the X endstop sensor wires, or the hotend heater/thermistor wires
  • the probe hole is the correct size - I've assumed 12.0mm and added 0.5mm for clearance
  • there's enough "meat" around the probe hole that it doesn't break easily

I expect that when assembling this, you'll need to install the probe before the Chimera hotend.

I also intend to add more mount holes so you can install the Chimera mount "backwards". Obviously not for printing, but this will let you access the rear set screws (that let you fine tune the height of each nozzle) for ensuring things are level with your bed, before re-installing the correct way around.
I took einarms' extruder mount and imported it into Tinkercad. Then put a few squares in places to remove the BLTouch mount and fill the area back in again as required.

author: petertee

title: Kossel Clear magball to Rostock Max V2/V3 Effector

description.text:
https://youtu.be/FPhVwWSVVz0

Effector mount that allows you to run any Rostock Max V2/V3 hotend and corresponding mounting solution including the E3D V6 and clones, or the HE280. I measured the mounting holes in the stock effector on the Kossel Clear magball effector and my roxmax V3 and came up with this. The end effect was that I was able to top-mount a volcano on an old unused printer and got it going again.

title: LWC  A.L.E.R.T airsoft motion detection alarm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The LWC A.L.E.R.T is a small and handy motion activated alert device you can simply place everywhere you want. It will feature a detachable thorn on its back so you can mount it on a tree or a wodden plates,car tires....just kidding XD ..... A.L.E.R.T also features 4 standing feet to put it on a flat surface.
Once A.L.E.R.T is placed you switch it on, and leave, after 30 seconds of calibration it will detect every movement nearby and will sound the alarm with two high tone piezo speakers in changing order for about 10 seconds! If movement in front of the sensor goes on of course it will keep going as well.

That way you can secure tactical important spots like a dorway or a path inside a wood. Sniper spot on the hill? No need to be surprised unprepared by enemy team players! A.L.E.R.T will alert you if someone tries to sneak up on you!

For the ZIP password contact me under lupusworax[at]gmail.com ( Of course free of charge!!)

Things you need for this build:

Arduino Nano:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-lot-Nano-3-0-controller-compatible-for-arduino-nano-CH340-USB-driver-NO-CABLE/32824272738.html?

1S lipo USB charging board:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/TP4056-1A-Lipo-Battery-Charging-Board-Charger-Module-lithium-battery-DIY-Mini-USB-Port-Free-shipping/32623939963.html

5 volt step up converter:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/5pc-DC-DC-Step-Up-Boost-Power-Supply-Module-2V-5V-to-5V-2A-Fixed-Output/32657938458.html

1x On/Off switch button:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/20pcs-Lot-7-7mm-latching-switch-Self-lock-On-Off-button-switch-double-row-self-locking/32818968898.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.sZFpN2

2x piezo buzzer:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/Hot-Sale-Durable-3-24V-Piezo-Electronic-Buzzer-Alarm-95DB-Continuous-Sound-Beeper-For-Arduino-Car/32670035011.html

2x2n2222 transistor:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/100PCS-LOT-in-line-2N2222A-triode-transistor-NPN-switching-transistors-TO-92-0-6A-30V-NPN/32624547567.html

1x mini infrared motion sensor:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/HC-SR505-Mini-Infrared-PIR-Motion-Sensor-Precise-Infrared-Detector-Module/32696432618.html?

1x Roll of polurethan enameled copper wire: ( because with small builds like this big wires are a ral pain trying to fit them in)
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/0-35-mm-x-50m-pc-Copper-wire-Free-Shipping-Navy-blue-Polyurethane-Enameled-Wire/32320066750.html

1x (un)protected 1S lipo cell:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-lot-Lipo-Battery-3-7v-600mah-for-RC-Quadcopter-rc-Drone-Syma-X5-X5A-X5SC/32468138416.html

1x Lipo protection circuit: ( if you order or use a unprotected lipo cell)
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/Protection-Circuit-Module-1S-4A-BMS-PCM-PCB-Battery-Protection-Board-For-3-7V-Li-ion/32623478043.html

Soldering iron,solder, hotglue gun, Metal thorn 3mm in diameter.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CBNUBgxiWzQ

description.text:
Et beaucoup de dispositifs de brouillage signaux maintenant sur le marché et l'utilisation normale du dispositif de suivi est un des dispositifs de suivi de signal de téléphone mobile et le dispositif de suivi GPS, donc si les gens ont besoin de couper le suivi du signal GPS et un dispositif de suivi brouilleur, si vous le souhaitez, vous peut venir directement, pour voir des exemples concrets de la conception de cette fonctionnalité, vous pouvez venir ici pour en savoir plus de détails sur cette « option de signal portable Bluetooth téléphone mobile 3G GPSL1 GPSL2 GPSL5 brouilleurs » et vous pouvez voir cette main téléphone mobile GPS 3G détails brouilleurs.
Ensuite, vous pouvez regarder ce signal portable en option brouilleurs brièvement. Ce bloqueur de poche WiFi 3G GPSL1 GPSL2 GPSL5, a GPSL1 GPSL2 GPSL5 des signaux et des signaux WiFi 2G 3G signal de téléphone mobile coupé simultanément. Mais par des conceptions alternatives, vous pouvez réellement besoin de décider en fonction de l'interférence de la bande. Par conséquent, étant donné que ce téléphone Bluetooth en option GPS 3G inclut également un chargeur de voiture bloquée, donc pour les personnes qui veulent utiliser Bluetooth GPSL1 GPSL2 GPSL5 3G brouilleurs de téléphone portable., il est également un bon choix.

Meilleurs brouilleurs

En outre, bloqueur de téléphone mobile GPS portable est également équipé d'un ventilateur intégré ventilateur comme le système de refroidissement, les signaux GPS téléphone portable de poche obturateur toujours maintenir un bon état de fonctionnement, ne conduira pas à une température élevée. En outre, le dispositif de blocage du signal GPS de poche portable est également conçu avec le chargeur de voiture, vous pouvez facilement utiliser le chargeur de voiture dans la voiture, ce qui est très pratique et facile à utiliser. En outre, Application brouilleur gps. est également très facile à utiliser, peut être utilisé dans de nombreux endroits, quand vous êtes sorti, ainsi que des salles de conférence, des salles de classe, etc. lieu.

Maintenant, avec la popularité des téléphones portables, téléphones brouilleur de gps une chose nouvelle, les gens veulent répondre aux demandes des personnes différentes, sur le marché de différents types de blocage de téléphone mobile pour les personnes à choisir. Selon l'application, le signal brouilleurs divisé pour l'industrie automobile, l'utilisation de bureau, un usage personnel, comme les écoles et les prisons utilisation des brouilleurs de signal. Ils sont principalement conçus pour être utilisés lorsque les brouilleurs de téléphone conçu, peut-être une voiture à son application unique.

Parfois, nous ne pouvons pas supporter d'entendre les appels bruyants, en particulier les téléphones mobiles ne sont pas autorisés dans les lieux publics. Pour faire face à ce problème, de sorte que ces gens tranquilles, pour l'usage personnel des brouilleurs de téléphone cellulaire sera d'une grande aide. De nombreux enseignants sont fatigués d'essayer d'arrêter les textos des étudiants en classe et veulent savoir comment arrêter l'utilisation du téléphone cellulaire dans la salle de classe. Utilisé par l'école pour mettre fin aux communications mobiles d'interférence.

Just spool-less and/or got some of that dirt cheap filament that questionable quality-often-hails-from-a-country without-Free-speech-nor-Freedom of assembly and that filament could most likely not even handle the neighbours cat breaking wind? Search no moar. Licence:
Design, parts, files: GPLv3.
Pics & doc: CC-BY-SA. Yahoodled with FreeCAD:
reprap.org/wiki/Freecad (Resources etc.) Easy to print.
Easy to customize.
Filament req: about 80grams. Use PLA!
Its moar awesome than any plastic you have not liberated/recycled yourself from the local dumpster.

Â· Download.
Â· Use your favourite slic3rs multiply function.
Â· Print two of the nave's -> sudo/pressfit those 608zz bearings in there while still hot. Â· Print six of those... Spoolheads, pacmanthingys, filamentbrains, hohohomerryCthulhu, filamentafro's, reprapreligious symbol/hat of the cloaked threaded rod brotherhood or "whatever one might conjure up for the moment-thingys". Â· Get out your favourite 6mm wood dowels or request a stl/adjust the files accordingly. Â· Measure your filament roll inner diameter, divide by two, subtract thirteen-ish and cut your dowels.
Â· Measure your filament roll width, add twenty and cut. Â· Assemble, one side + the bearing dowels.
Â· Test fit & adjust.
Â· Satisfied? Dab some glue here and there.
Â· Use! I have loaded it with 3kg(6.6lb) so far and will use it with 5kg as soon as it comes out of my printer. Still not satisfied?
Learn by fire up FreeCAD and doodle. When you know the jest of it:
In the nave file, there are two radius values. One as ref.(608zz), the other to fiddle with.
Realign the three dowel connectors.
Choose the object to export choose 'meshformats' and create your .stl! N.B; And the file isn't as clean as it should, aka will fix if memory serves or comments for as an incentive. Same goes for the spoolhead file.

The experimenter's resistor pseudo-decade box. It's not a real decade but two precision "ten turn" pots of different values (http://ebay.to/2zpSskz) and a hard coded resistor at the end in series gives a lot of flexibility for the experimenter on a budget. I use a 1k Ohm pot, a 50k Ohm pot, and a 1M ohm hard coded resistor for lots of options. You can bypass or simply change the last 1M resistor via banana jacks if needed.

Knob options are plenty, but I used and love this openSCAD option (kudos): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54024

title: PS4 & XBOX ONE analog joystick adapters kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[ENG]
Parts of this kit allow you to build the convenience of using the controller joystick for PS4 and XBOX One. This could be also an aid for pepople with disability.

This project is inspired by the beautiful Modular Thumbstick Extender of caleb kraft.

We started from di Pit Foxx's Analog Stick Caps PS4 base, which seemed very well done and we also adapted it for XBOX ONE.

Then we improved the fixing system of the accessories by adding lateral holes in order to insert the screws and give more stability to the object. Alternatively you can use glue.

We have included some accessories inspired by the Modular Thumbstick Extender such as elliptical handles and joints, and we also inserted a joystick inspired by the CEAPAT Joystick game controller and an "experimental fork"

[ITA]
Le parti di questo kit permettono di costruire delle facilitazioni all'uso del joystick analogico dei controller per PS4 ed XBOX One da parte di persone disabili e non solo.

Questo progetto è ispirato al bellissimo Modular Thumbstick Extender di caleb kraft.

Siamo partiti dalla base per PS4 Analog Stick Caps di Pit Foxx che ci è sembrata molto ben fatta e l'abbiamo riadattata anche per XBOX ONE.

Poi abbiamo migliorato il sistema ad incastro degli accessori aggiungendo dei fori laterali per poter inserire delle viti e dare più solidità all'oggetto. In alternativa è possibile utilizzare della colla.

Abbiamo inserito nel kit alcuni accessori ispirati al Modular Thumbstick Extender come le maniglie ellittiche e lo snodo, abbiamo inserito anche un joystick ispirato al progetto Joystick game controller di CEAPAT ed una maniglia sperimentale a "forchetta"

The original was impossible to print with all the support needed, so i created a new version where there are 6 individual pieces. only the legs need a tiny amount of support (print these standing with a skirt with a size of 10 outlines to prevent it from falling over or moving too much)

i havent got as far as installing any lithophanes and lighting but will do that soon.

I have a 140x140x140 bed, so these STL files uploaded will give you a lithophane size of around 113.4mm

instructions:
1.Turn the cover 180degrees so it lays flat

  1. create 4 sockle_legs print it standing.

you can print it with .3 or .2 and a 30-40% infill
only the sockle_legs need support and a skirt of at least 10 outlines

if you have a larger printer, you can offcourse scale up everything and measure the distance yourselve.

description.text:
This is the basic cut info for a layered Bombardier bilevel passenger car, as seen on GO Transit/Metrolink/Coaster etc. trains.

This layout has 1 exterior and 3 interior layers on a 300mm-square (1') sheet.

The interior layers have a "stair" ramp from lower to mid-level, and another from mid-level to the top-level. I laid 2 layers in one direction, the the other 2 in the other direction so the tiny people could climb to the top floor.

I used a 6.35mm-thick sheet (1/4"), set into 6 layers, which roughly fits the scale -- 90% of HO, or 3:261. It might look better to have the exteriors be thinner to match the actual wall thickness -- 3mm or thinner sheets, with 1 or 2 more interior layers.

I added HO wheelsets. I had to use metal ones, since the plastic ones couldn't handle the girth of these cars. I also want to try one with Brio wheels.

I had no idea how enormous these things actually are. They dwarf all the other train cars that I have, even at 90% scale.

Couplers should also connect to the ends at a decent height.

There is a hole on each side for inserting a 6.4mm (1/4") dowel to keep the layers aligned.

I recommend sandwiching a piece of this transparent film inside the exterior for the tiny windows.

Todo:

  • Doors on each end
  • Outline the size doors

Printer:

Epilog Helix

Notes:

This is lasercut, not 3D-printed :)

title: SMARS modular robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://youtu.be/JCqkuDWNzIg
SMARS acronym of “Screwless/Screwed Modular Assemblable Robotic System” is a simple robot designed to the educational field. The main features of SMARS are the reduced number of components, the possibility of mount it without screws and without soldering any part, it doesn’t need glue or similar and it’s really cheap to build. Another main point of SMARS is the modular design. You can mount different sensors and tools and design your own parts. In future I’ll add new modules or DLC to improve the model on my Cults 3D page (https://goo.gl/xK9s1V) but It would be nice if you could share your mods too.

Join the Facebook group! https://goo.gl/4EgJhX
Facebook page: https://goo.gl/Gcmxp5

To build the basic model (with “chassis -SL.stl”) you just need few extra components:
-2x mini 150RPM motors https://goo.gl/FK7nvk
-1x 9[V] battery (you can find it in a local shop)
-1x 9[V] battery connector https://goo.gl/P5gYos
 or https://goo.gl/F1wWUd
-1x Arduino UNO or 2009 https://goo.gl/6nCCMZ
 or https://goo.gl/gNpttN
-1x Adafruit Motor Shield V1 or V2 https://goo.gl/n9rXvW
or an L298P motor shield https://goo.gl/aHG2z7

For the screwed version ( “chassis -S.stl”) you just need two 25mm M4 screws and two self locking nuts.

TIPS:
The joints of the tracks are simply pieces of 1.75mm filament cutted at the right length.

To assemble the screwless version you will need a multi slip-joint gripping plier to insert the “slave wheels”.

One of the next DLC will be the Quadpod mod. if you are interessted to move from tracks to legs, use the screwed version “chassis-S.stl” (“chassis-SL” will not be compatible)!

Building instructions are in the "doc lite" folder.

These models fits also:
-3x AAA batteries (check on my profile for the DLC)
-1x PS3 controller 1800mAh 3.7V Li-Ion Battery (be careful and use it only if you
know what you are doing!) https://goo.gl/AR6pjf

P.S
If you like my projects, just tip me or support me buying the material from my links, it will not cost you extra money and you will allow me to finance new projects! I would really appreciate it!

Printer:

BQ Witbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

only the "chassis_SL" needs supports (touching building plate)

SMARS This robot is really easy to build and cheap. It can be assembled without screws or soldering and it's modular so it can be adapted for different purposes. I'm Swiss, so I don't know American scholastic system but I would use SMARS in last year of middle school, high school or universities/ colleges. There is more "open electronics" compared to a Lego NXT or similar, so students need a few knowledges about security, electrical laws and so on. It can be use to improve software development skills, CAD skills or electronics skills, students can design their own modules and customize their SMARS.
Lesson plan and Student documentation concept I uploaded a lesson plan and a concept of the documentation (you need to write a new one, mine is just indicative)
Materials All the materials needed and instructions are in the general informations and in the "doc_lite" folder

• CAD
  • programming
  • soldering
  • manual skills
  • electronics
  • robotics
  • mechanics
  • Arduino programming
2x 45min lessons

print_settings.Notes:: I used 0.1mm layer height for the bulb.
print_settings.Infill:: On the base, not the bulb

description.text:
In Christmas times in Sweden, by tradition we keep these kind of lights in the windows. Usually they use small incandescant bulbs. (don't know exactly why we do this, maybe because it's so dark outdoors).

I thought I would design something a bit more fun around this concept.

This design uses LED's that slowly change color. They start in sync and then as time passes they get kind of random. It's a calm effect, not stressfully blinking.

This requires a bit of soldering but it's quite simple. I have included an electrical drawing and some links to the stuff needed on ebay.

The design is made to run on 5V DC, with the suggested cable this could be supplied through and USB charger or similar USB port. It uses less than 200 mA current.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 and 0.2mm

Infill:

On the base, not the bulb

Notes:

Ok, some details.

The base first.

I used: Fillamentum Extrafill PLA Vertigo Grey (www.fillamentum.com)

The base should be printed standing up, not lying down as it is modelled.
I have included two versions. One without support and one with some extra pillars preventing the arms from bending upwards.

You should also use splicer generated support.

NOTE! Avoid support inside the arm because this is where you will have to thread the wires through.

I used 0.2mm layer height for the base

The buld

For the bulb I used: Fillamentum PLA Crystal Clear (www.fillamentum.com)

The buld should also be printed upright.
I used a brim here to give it some extra support.
The buld can be printed without supports.
The bulb should be printed without infill.

I used 0.1mm layer height for the bulb.

post print cleanup

If you used the base model with extra support you can trim the excess plastic using for example a side cutter.

Trim off the excess brim that you might have used. The fitting between buld and bas is quite exact, so you should avoid having excess material there

Assembly

There are included images that show some of the below steps.

  1. Solder the resistor to the positive side of the LED (Positive side is the one with a longer leg)

  2. Solder a long enough red wire to the other side of the resistor. Put shrink tubing around wire and resistor

  3. solder a black wire to the negative side of the resistor. Put shrink tubing around the joint.

  4. place the LED inside the buld. as far in as possible. there is an edge it will sit against. I had to trim away some excess fillament to get it in perfect.

  5. Secure the LED with some hot glue or similar.

  6. Thread the wire through the arm. for help I used a piece of fillament that I cut, heated and folded one end of, then it slides nicely through the arm, I then taped the wires to this and pulled them trough.

  7. repeat step 1-6 for each of the seven arms.

  8. when all wires are thread to the bottom of the base, trim them of in a suitable length.

  9. Solder all 7 red wires to one of the poles on the connector. Se electrical drawing for which one is positive (Red).

  10. Solder all 7 black wires to one of the poles on the connector. Se electrical drawing for which one is negative (black).

  11. Fix the connector in its hole using hot glue or similar. If you have printed the version with extra support, it is a bit tight. In this case it is OK to brake away the centa support pillar, it's bascically ony there to support the cealing while printing.

  12. Put the USB cable in the base, and the other side in a USB charger. It should now light up. If there is no light the most probable cause is that the led's are connected backwards.
Links

Ok, here are links to some of the parts used (I guess that you can also use some local electronics shop for the parts):

LED:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/50pcs-5mm-Diffused-RGB-Rainbow-Slow-Flashing-Flash-Red-Green-Blue-LED-Leds-/400985246280?hash=item5d5c954a48

Connector:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/10PCS-DC-Power-Supply-5-5-x-2-1mm-Jack-Socket-Female-Panel-Mount-Connector-3-Pin-/222324942267?hash=item33c39965bb

USB Cable:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/USB-Port-to-5-5mm-2-1mm-5V-DC-Barrel-Jack-Power-Cable-Connector-FEVD/162334113426?epid=836207601&hash=item25cbddfe92:g:P64AAOSwnHZYYOD5

Fillament (bulb):
https://fillamentum.com/collections/pla-extrafill/products/pla-extrafill-crystal-clear

Fillament (Base):
https://fillamentum.com/collections/pla-extrafill/products/pla-extrafill-vertigo-galaxy

Resistors:
This is easiest to source locally. They should be 47Ohm 1/4 watts. Any electronics shop should have some.

description.text: Reifen 14,4x8x7 gerundete Flanken

This is a normal vat, compressed from one side near the Z axis and with a bite missing to allow for a THK KR26 linear actuator.

Use a soldering iron to insert "M4 x 10mm Brass Cylinder Knurled Threaded Round Insert Embedded Nuts" and fasten the FEP with the gasket with "M4x6mm Metric Hex Socket Flat Head Screw Bolts Fasteners."
Reifen 9x17x10

Made for my CJ18A minilathe, will probably fit most asian 7" swing machines.

The dial lock will require a M10 thread being tapper through the bore. Using a countersink to chamfer the ends really helps to keep the tap true.

You also need to drill and tap two M3 holes, about 10mm deep. 39mm apart and 3.5mm down from the top of the compound slide upper, hole should be 5mm from the edges of the compound. There is also a drilling jig to help you line your holes up, works best in a drill press (a drill can wobble and will chew up the jig but it can last long enough to give you a lil crater to start free hand drilling into)

The thrust bracket takes a 6900 ball bearing and is designed to be a light press fit. I held the bracket against the closed chuck jaws and used the tailstock to push the bearing in. You could use a vice or a hammer (gently).
A thrust bearing is put under the Dial lock so it can be tightened without transmitting the rotation to the dial. On ebay it was an AXK thrust bearing 10x24x4.

The bush goes between the bearing and the dial.

I think you could make this on literally any printer. No part is large or very complicated. I made mine out of PLA for lack of options (no heated bed). Ultimately I will recreate this is steel cos y'know thats what a lathe is for.

then find a nice metal coat hanger and cut the strait part out of the bottom with a set of side-cutters. poke it in the appropriate hole.
slide your rocket on.
hook up the electronics. (or stuff the fuse in)
then light 'er up!

Hi friends,

I made a new version of my blockbuster screwmeter ;) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2624098

Here are the changes:

  • I added new sizes: 4 and 5 mm
  • Because of these new sizes, I had to rework the slider more accurately to have a good precision. I suggest you to put soap on it before using it.
  • I reduced the thickness on a large part of the principal bloc. Less filament is needed and printing is faster.
  • I integrated the idea of J-Max. Now, the slider has holes for 2.5, 3 and 4mm screws but also a universal notch.
  • As I always loose the slider, I made a hole for a screw (M3 10 or 12mm) and a notch on the slider to hang a rubber band. It should be held with a washer. No more loss ! I like that.
  • I have had a thought for left-handed users. I made a new reversed version. Use "screwmeter v2 left-h.stl" file. I have not printed it (I'm righ-handed ;). So if you notice something wrong, let me a comment.

The link to see how it works : https://image.noelshack.com/fichiers/2017/44/5/1509730896-video.gif

I hope all these evolutions will please you.

Bonjour chez vous.

description.text:
Some quick and easy tealight holders for the festive season. They take standard 40mm tealights. I printed them in PETG, but PLA wouldn't be a problem.

Some people might wonder about the things melting, but a quick check on this site will ahow that there are dozens of designs. I tested these continuously all day and the sides of the holder and the base were barely warm. I made some basic holders which have been in use for months without a trace of deformation or heat damage.

I've included the Autodesk Inventor files for anyone who wants to adapt the models or look at how I constructed them.

V.2 Changed Geometry a bit and it's smaller. you'll see in pictures I added a piece of Poly Tube just to smooth it out more not need if you don't have any. Works really good. Enjoy it.

Also note the trim piece in the cover slot this allows the material to slide in the Horizontal slot easier also reducing catches in the vertical slot which has caused mine to jamb.

description.text:
Yet another anti z wobble part.
I use it on my GeeeTech i3, but it should fit on other printers with an M8 lead screw and an 8 mm ⌀ guide rod. (Maybe not the Anet A8, that may have a proper lead screw)

This one is reasonably flat, so you should not have to move up your printing platform, as i had with some of the other designs i tried. With this, the force of the x axis assembly completely rests on the M8 nut. The smooth rod arms are used only for the torque on the nut. They act only as a wrench, not transferring vertical forces and are flat enough to fit under the sliding bearings on the rod.

You’ll need a pair of standard¹ M8 hex nuts.

The picture with the red parts are a before and after comparison. It’s philbarrenger’s monster mouth headphone holder, which i reprinted to get rid of the “nail file” ridges, once i had found out what the problem was.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Notes:

Print settings are not critical. No rafts or falsework needed.

• Sand the top of the main part and the plastic washers, so the x axis connector can slide to and fro on this, which is the whole point.
  • Press in the nuts
  • Install
  • Make sure x axis is horizontal
  • Re-adjust z end-stop
  • Re-level the bed
  • Use

The washer is a simple OpenSCAD part. The main part was designed in FreeCAD. I added both files. The FreeCAD file contains a spreadsheet, where the sizes can be changed somewhat easily.

There is some design history available at my github repo. For this it is a bit more interesting then for my other parts, as i tried a few designs before settling on this one.

¹ Literally, of course. ISO 4032.
askefiulrtfv6byguvleria;o/fh.uks,rejfd
Simple button. I hope you will like it.

Some bits to make a bucky tube space frame. This is a simple tube as shown on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:263765
It has 8 faces per layer.
Printed at full scale it has 6mm holes. Plastic drinking straws were used in the photo above to show how it goes together. I don't recommend straws.
Using something like wooden dowel - quite large tubes could be made.
Printed at 2 to 3 times scale something like curtain rods or tent poles could be used to make a fairly serious structure - think shade house.
The tube shape alone may not be all that useful but joined to a dome and other shapes some neat stuff could be made.

I printed in PLA and cleaned the holes with a 6mm drill.
The ratio of long and short rods is not quite 2:1 but 2:1 should be close enough. 100mm and 50mm were used in the demo but longer would be more impressive.
The long rods are optional.

To prevent messing up the Z coordinate when changing filament during a print and for a dual extruder setup I decided to move my extruder(s) to the top bar of my CR-10.
This thing also allows the extruder steppers to swivel left/right to reduce strain on the bowden tube when printing tall objects.

You will need
1 37x25x7 bearing
4 M4 T-slot nuts
4 M4 10mm screws
1 60cm bowden tube

optionally you can add a stepper damper between the ExtruderMountPlate and the StepperSleeve.

The height of the StepperSleeve prongs should be adjusted to fit your stepper's base plate height to properly click into place.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

A simple camera mount for the Fly Egg 100 frame from King Kong. I made it because the included one didn't fit my camera. It should work for any of the really small micro cameras with a lens that's 10mm or smaller. (Not the runcam micros, they're too big to fit the frame) Just print and use rubber bands to hold the camera in place. I'm not sure if this will work with the cameras that have the built in VTX, the antenna placement might interfere.

I don't know the exact angle, but it looks like it's around 30 degrees.

Just a man. Made using makehuman and sculptris for my freaky Hannibal 'Dolls house'

I needed a way to attach a piece of glass (4mm thick in my case) the same xy dimensions (225mm x 225mm) as my platform below it (mdf) without cutting holes into the glass.
These are holders to do such a thing.
There are spots for m3 screws to level into and the glass slides into the sliders, with smaller m3 screws to secure it tight.
Stl files may be useful if you have pretty much the same setup with a 4mm glass and the same screw size. If not, you can use the scad files to edit.

They are slim so that they don't rub up against the threaded rods on a mendel/prusa type. Print a set of ( Top + Bottom ) x 4, Use your m3 screws holding the bed to go inside the bottom holder. You will need to undo any springs etc first.
Use a smaller m3 screw and nut to secure the glass in place. These are designed so they don't need to go over the x edge, as not to hit threaded rods.

title: Y Adapter for 1.75mm filament dual extruders and single nozzle

description.text:
I have tried few y adapter from other posting, but never found one that works for me. I decided to make one myself.

Few things I found to make the design better.

  1. inbound wider tunnel, 3mm diameter, to receive filament. To avoid hitting tunnel wall when feeding filament from PC4-M6 fittings
  2. outbound 2mm diameter tunnel to feed filament. To avoid hitting PC4 or PTFE wall when feeding filament from the adapter
  3. avoiding sharp curve and S-curve in the tunnel
  4. It works better with PC4-M6(bore 4.3mm), because the PTFE will fit against the inbound or outbound tunnels.
  5. It also works with PC4-M6(bore 2mm) if you can enlarge the 2mm hole a bit by using a small round chisel.
  6. I also tested with retracted filament that usually form a bulging end.
  7. I tested with a small filament roll which curved the filament in smaller diameter.

The M6 threads might be a bit tight, so you might need a wrench to screw the fitting in. 11/24/2017: I printed my very first dual filament piece, and it worked great. I use Marlin 1.1.6 with the single nozzle option. Cura 3.0 does not support single nozzle, so I went into gcode remove anything reference to T1(the second hotend).

I am also working a Y-adapter using M3 snap ring instead of using any PC4-M6 fittings. I will post it soon.

title: Teal Sport Video Ball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Flying POV globe

It's a POV globe that can fly. You can 'place' it whereever you want, as long you can fly there. Then, to display an image, the drone will hover at this location and rotate around it's own axis (center of gravity). The symmetric design keeps vibration low.

Possible areas of use:
-Flying information
-Advertisement at unusal locations
Or just fly around for fun and pretend to be an UFO with a small green man waving to mankind.

Around the ring is a total of 360 LEDs (Type 0805, 2mm x 1.02mm) for illustration only, you can get good results also with much fewer LEDs as shown in the attached video below.

A POV ball with instructables (it can't fly):

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hJ131h3C1HZ

The TRAV 2.0 project is well on its way. In case anyone wants to follow along, I will post the process here.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722396

Background:

I built the original Trav (Terra Roving Autonomous Vehicle) back in 2015. It was built on an a hobby grade rc electric 4x4 truck.

Goal:

The goal is to not only have a functional rover, but to make it strong enough to go crawling with my buds. This is proving to be more difficult than first thought because of the known abuse the crawlers take and the diverse terrain they drive in. This is from mud to water to rock crawling and everything in between.

Trav 2.0 will have autonomous with obstacle avoidance as well as human control capabilities with planned GPS support as well. It is designed around the NASA Curiosity Rover (minus the MMRTG power plant of course :) ) It will have independent 6 wheel drive and 4 wheel steering. 3 steering modes and the rocker bogie suspension. 3S battery will power Trav.

New Branch is Here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722396

Build Status 12-19-2017
I am still waiting on my new hotbed. In the meantime, I have almost finished the new design. I have decided to branch it out as TRAV 2.1 due to all of the changes. I have redesigned almost everything. I decided that I didn't like the rounded edges as much and I also reduced the bulkiness of the suspension parts. I posted more parts for this build, but, remember that I am abandoning it. Consider them as freebies. :) I hope to see you all over at the new build. I will post a link to it shortly.

Build Status 12-15-2017
The build is hold for the moment. A sensor wire came off of my hotbed, so I am going to go ahead and put the larger bed on it. I think I am going to change the design of the chassis. The main reason is a design flaw. The problem is that it takes days to print the front and rear chassis sections. The second reason is that I am not 100% sold on the looks. I started working on a new chassis design that takes much less time to print and looks better according to a few people that I have asked. I added the picture as a sneak peek. I will most likely also tweak the suspension parts to match the design.

Build Status 12-12-2017
The rear chassis printed successfully. I also tweaked the shock clips. Two per side will now be used and I eliminated the shock mount on the lower bogie joint. This gives greater articulation and more adjustment. (see new mock up image)

Build Status: 12-10-2017
I woke up this morning to find that my bowden had a blowout with ~10 hours to go. :( I decided to decrease the resolution down to .15. That will shave off ~18 hours off of the print. Let's try it again.

Build Status: 12-8-2017
I just started printing the rear chassis section. The print time is ~48 hours at 60mm p/sec @ .1 resolution. 40% infill. I made my own support structures to help speed it up a bit. PLEASE NO POWER OUTAGES!!! ...again. I have an UPS but, it only lasts about 20 minutes.

I have also built the MMRTG, jk. :) I built the 3S battery using some 18650's. 12 of them at 2950 mah each. It has a 11850 mah capacity. I also am ready to cut the carbon fiber tubes for the suspension. I hope to have that done this weekend.

I have decided against making a boom for the sensors, etc., at least for now. Instead I am going to mount the SONAR on the front and use a servo to sweep it. I am undecided about the camera. Still need to buy one. The front deck will be a modular addition to allow for more flexibility.

Build Status: 12-2-2017
I have 2 more suspension parts to print out and then off to the chassis. The chassis only lacks the inside shelf for the Arduino and various other electronics. I started designing the boom and upper portion that will hold the sensors, camera, and light(s). Using the square block made it look like a hammer, so I had some fun and made Thor's hammer. :) I also designed some motor covers to protect the wires. This will be a must when going crawling.
Take care,

Build Status: 11-29-2017
All of the suspension parts are done. I think... I took advantage of Servocity's Cyber Monday sale and bought the servo mounts, block bearings, and servo shafts. I am well on the way of completing the chassis. I have went thru several revisions and I believe I am happy with the over all design. Off to the details. Items left on the to do list is to finish the top and inside of the rover and some various details. I will be adding 3mm LEDs and a couple of large melt your eyeball LEDs that one of my buds gave me. One will be mounted in the front and one on the boom.

Build Status: 11-24-2017
I have put in many hours is CAD over the past two days. I uploaded the servo steering mounts. I will not be using these, however. For my tire sizes, they protruded over the approach angles. The one I will be using are set at a 90 degree angle to the rover.

I also finished all of the motor mounts, steering shaft bearing holder, and upper bogie arm joints.

I will be using bearings in the joints and chassis. I am planning on putting them in the lower bogie arm ends and the chassis. The locations might change. As the Thingiverse warning states, all things are subject to change, though I am trying to only post finished stl's.

Build Status: 11-22-2017
Most of the electronics have made it in and I have printed several test parts and started printing the first of the finished parts as well. I still have several more hours of CAD to finish. Pictured is a crude initial mockup of the finished motor mounts and steering servo mounts.

I will require larger build plate on my printer, so I have a 220x275 hotbed and necessary parts on the way.

Parts List

Carbon Fiber Tube x2
Size: OD 20Mm X ID 18Mm X L 500Mm

6x10x3 Flanged Bearings x4 for the upper bogie joint that connects to the chassis. These fit in to the chassis side. Used these because that was what I had.

5x10x4 Bearings x4 for the lower bogie joint that attaches both tires and has the shock mount.

16GA Wire for Motors
65mm Shock Absorbers x2
130mm Shock Absorbers x2
Hobbywing 1040 60A Waterproof Brushed ESC x2
MG996R Servo's x5
12vdc 300rpm Motor x6
https://www.ebay.com/itm/12V-DC-3-5RPM-300RPM-Torque-Magnetic-Mini-Electric-Motor-for-DIY-Toys-Cars-SA1/222679745925?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=521534402905&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

4mm to 12mm hex Shaft Coupler
https://www.ebay.com/itm/3-4-5-6-7-8-mm-Brass-Shaft-Couplings-Coupler-Motor-12MM-Hex-connector-DIY-Screws/181739759207?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=480686801263&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

Servo Mount and Servo Shaft from Servocity

Hardware

m3 x 30mm, lock nuts x2 - Shock Clips
m6 x 100mm, washers, lock nuts x2 - Upper Bogie Joint
m5 x 65mm, washers, lock nuts x2 - Lower Bogie Joint
m4 x 14mm, washers x6 - Wheels
m3 x 6mm x4 - Servo
m3 x 40mm, lock nuts x16 - Servo Joints

6 - 32 x 3/8" x16 - Servo Mounts - Servocity

6 - 32 x 3/8" x16 - Servo Shaft - Servocity

m3 x 25mm, washers, lock nuts x6 - Motor Mounts
m3 x 25mm, lock nuts x6 - Servo Coupling to Motor Mount
m3 x 15mm, lock nuts x8 - Servo Bearing Retainer
m3 x 35mm, lock nuts x16 - Carbon Tubes to Mounts
m2.5 x20mm, washers, lock nuts x4 - Shock Mounts

1) The bearing retainer must be installed in the correct rotation. It is not bidirectional.
2) Almost all of the suspension parts have a left and right version.
3) The 130mm shocks only have a few drops of oil in them in order to lubricate the O rings. The only function for them is to stop the lower bogie system from spinning around too much.
I am already planning on stream lining the servo mounts. They are a bit bulky and can be thinned down a bit. - The front mounts have been updated. I was off by 7 degrees and thinned the sides.

SPECIAL THANKS!!!!

I would like to give a special thanks to the following people for giving me great ideas in my design and build process. I did remix the steering bearing holder from tslove28 as well. These folks have made some very cool builds. Check them out!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hteHGmeRZfq
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/

I am posting my plans to the enclosure for the CR-10.

I made mine quite a bit wider so I can change filament and get to extruder easily, but I left minimum dimensions as well. I reused spool holder from CR-10 and mounted to frame.

Here is most everything you will need:

Aluminum tube 30 mm x 30 or 1 /4” x 1 1/4

Foam sealing tape (26' was just too short of the large cabinet size, will need two orders)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07477J8KL/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Hinge hardware www.cshardware.com
54.25.02 hinges 4 pairs
54.27.02 slip on catch 4 pcs
58.22.08 strong double magnetic latch 4 pcs

Desk hole cover
https://www.amazon.com/Organizer-Computer-Entertainment-Workstation-Tabletop/dp/B075P4H7F2/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?ie=UTF8&qid=1511366349&sr=8-1-spons&keywords=cable+hole+cover+for+desk&psc=1

Plywood Top and Bottom 1/2" 2 pcs : 28 5/16 x 25 11/16

1/4” Acrylic Sheet (measure final openings in your sides and subtract 10 mms from all directions to leave a gap of 5 mms all around)

Self tapping screws for aluminum, wood screws for wood to wood

If you make one from my designs please post your photos here!

title: Blood and Bone - Abyssal Scenery - 28mm gaming - Sample Items

description.text:
Expose your players to the gut-wrenching horrors of the abyss with this "Blood and Bone" abyssal scenery pack for 28mm gaming! This Thingiverse release includes a few free items from my new scenery pack available on Hero's Hoard.

Included items:

  • Altar w/ basic blood pools
  • 2 Solid obelisk variations

Not included:

  • More cool altar varieties, including bits of bone/charnel, blood flow channels, and fountains
  • Obelisks hollowed out to accept a Chinese LED Earring with threaded bottom
  • Archway and bridge with blood channels, bone, and charnel (this pieces is awesome!)

These models print with no supports and paint up quickly and easily with a few base coats and a wash or two. All examples in the pics are printed @ .12 layer height.

If you like these items, please check out the full set on Hero's Hoard, and follow EC3D on Facebook where I give away premium model sets to a follower twice a month!

comments.text: I went ahead and purchased the other stuff on DrivethruRPG. Cool stuff but you may want to use Zip files in the future, takes 2 downloads to get all your stuff.
comments.author: Kirshan

comments.text: Hope you enjoy, and thanks for the feedback! My process of optimizing files is much improved, even over that release and I will be sure to include a zip file in the future! Was my first post on Drive Thru so wasn't sure if they listed the individual assets -wanted it to be obvious how the STL files were all split up. Thanks again!
comments.author: Kirshan

title: Warhammer Quest (1995) Chaos Warrior Proxies
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm working on a complete set of printed proxies to cover the entire range of possible rolls on all 10 levels of the monster tables from the WHQ Roleplay Book.

I only ever owned the base set, and I always wanted to collect them all but could never afford it when they were still on the market.

I've leaned heavily on dutchmogul's amazing collection of gaming miniatures. Some of these figures are only resized versions of his, some are modded versions of his, and a rare few are scratch modeled by me.

I've gone through the list and pared it down as much as possible. My goal is to handle any given roll, but not worry about trying to cover any two rolls... I chose not to distinguish between a Savage Ork and a Black Ork, for example, and I only considered An Ork to differ from and Ork champion if they could both appear on the same roll. I wasn't too uptight about hand weapons... Swords, Spears, Axes... whatever. So you basically end up with Orks, a Big Ork, and a Bigger Ork. Finally, if you have 2D6 goblins that you roll for bows or spears, I choose to take that as 1D6 w/bow and 1D6 with spears to keep the numbers down, but print as many as you want!

This is the Chaos Warriors, up to battle level 10, Chaos is vast, and just easier to break up a little. More races to follow.

12 Chaos Warriors
6 Chaos Champions
3 Chaos Sorcerer
1 Chaos Lord / Master Sorcerer
4 Chaos Warrior Rider (~Juggernaut of Khorne)

I deeply appreciate tips if you like my work, but in this case please consider sending some love dutchmogul's way, as his amazing work made this possible!
